rsbNotes.title: Ps 6
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 6 The psalm is an individual lament. As with many laments, the psalmist expresses his trust in the Lord at the end of the psalm. The occasion of the psalm appears to be a severe illness (vv. 2, 5). This psalm is one of seven “penitential psalms” (along with 32; 38; 51; 102; 130; 143).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 6:1
rsbNotes.text: 6:1 rebuke . . . discipline. The psalmist begs the Lord to refrain from verbal and physical punishment. Though God disciplines His people (Heb. 12:1–13), it is for correction and not destruction.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 6:2
rsbNotes.text: 6:2 I am languishing . . . my bones are troubled. The psalmist experiences suffering, probably a serious illness. Some take the language as figurative for spiritual distress.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 6:3
rsbNotes.text: 6:3 how long. The psalmist boldly asks how long God will permit his suffering to continue. He desperately seeks relief from the One who is able to give it.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 6:4
rsbNotes.text:
6:4 Turn, O Lord. The psalmist thinks that God has turned away from him.

the sake of your steadfast love. The word translated “steadfast love” indicates how devotedly God binds Himself to His people by His covenant.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 6:5
rsbNotes.text:
6:5 no remembrance. A similar statement is expressed in 30:9. The doctrine of resurrection, like the doctrine of the Trinity, is implicit in the Old Testament, but not developed fully until the New Testament. The living observe that the dead are silent and do not take part in worship.

Sheol. This word is found most often in poetic passages that reveal the thoughts and fears of the living, but are not presentations of a doctrine of resurrection or of the intermediate state. See Is. 14:9–11 note.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 6:8
rsbNotes.text: 6:8 all you workers of evil. This reference, along with the reference to “foes” in the preceding verse, is abrupt. It is possible that the foes are people, like the “friends” of Job, who blamed the patient’s sickness on his sin.
